baseline_groups.claim_summary: Flooded counties in the 1927 Mississippi flood experienced larger relative declines in Black population share in subsequent decades, consistent with the flood accelerating Black out-migration from the South.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline coefficient 0.026 (SE 0.054, p=0.633) -- POSITIVE and insignificant. The SPECIFICATION_SEARCH.md notes weak support. The expected sign based on the paper's hypothesis is negative (flood reduces Black share), but the baseline specification shows a positive coefficient. County and year FE are included. Many control variations (lagged DV) failed to produce results.

global_notes: Paper is 'When the Levee Breaks' (AER). The baseline specification yields a positive, insignificant coefficient, contrary to expectations. Many specifications (7 of 57) produced missing results due to data issues with lagged dependent variables. Cross-sectional specifications (1930, 1950, 1960, 1970) show large positive coefficients because they capture level differences rather than within-county changes. The two-way FE specification (county + year) yields a negative coefficient (-0.072). Results are highly sensitive to FE structure.
